text: Quick cuts, seductive angles: 70 hot-air balloons rise ov a vast, green corporate campus. Their mylar skins are  imprinted with Outpost '98 logos; their gondolas are dres in Outpost-colored bunting. 18,000 Outpost employees cheer. They're spread out over  rolling lawns, amid Arabian tents and costumed Acrobats.  Over the balloon-dotted sky, the graphic re-appears: "The coolest thing?"
It's the beverages.
A Programmer sits in his handsome office, forested landsc out the window. The screen says: DARYL, M.I.T. '95
Gary always makes sure we've got the  coolest stuff to drink.
JUMP CUTS of tall refrigerators: Snapples, Cokes, Fruitop Zaps, Jolts, Barques & Sprites are lined-up behind glass  doors. "The coolest thing?"
Knowing your work means something.
A 24-year-old Korean-American Girl sits at the edge of a  plashing, post-modern fountain. DIANA, STANFORD '97
Knowing everywhere in the world,  this is the software people use.
MONTAGE of world capitals & remote places: Stockbrokers & Farmers, News Anchors & Students, CEO's & Eskimos boot-up Outpost '98, or log-on with Outpost Internet Traveler.
20 years ago, Gary had an idea, that's  all he had. And now the company's  bigger than IBM.
Over the last shot (a Ghetto Kid uses Outpost Word in the library): "The coolest thing?"
It's the people. Which is weird.
A Programmer sits with two colleagues, drinking lattes at the edge of Lake Washington. MITCH, BERKELEY, '98
Big companies are s'posed to be  impersonal.

MONTAGE: Programmers play competitive games at an Outpost picnic; Toddlers play on computers in an Outpost Day Care Center; Geeks confer at a diagram-covered whiteboard;  Employees listen/dance to the Seattle band we've been hea on-stage, at the Outpost '98 launch.
There's this myth that doing a start- up is cooler. But there's no community  with a start-up. No permanence.
One of Mitch's colleagues is nodding. DONNY, HARVARD, '97
It bums me out when the media say  we're cultish, or whatever. Why?  'Cause we care about each other?
Donny didn't mean to sound so mushy. Nobody knows where t look for a second.
'Love you too, bro.
As they laugh: "The coolest thing?"
I'll tell you what's not cool.
How Gary gets this superbad rap.

MONTAGE of magazine covers (Newsweek, Vanity Fair, WIRED) featuring Gary Boyd. They say, eg: "Who Owns Cyberspace?" a Time cover, he's composited by the Capitol Dome: "ROBBE BARON OR VISIONARY? Outpost's Antitrust Woes"
There's this prejudice against super- smart people. People like Gary.
GARY (early 40's) reads a statement before a Congressiona Sub-Committee. His voice is pleasant but firm:
A kid working in his garage can create  the next Outpost, the new IBM. All  it takes is a great idea.
A bloated Senator looks hostile.
That's why nobody can have a monopoly  in a business built on ideas.
As we watch, CAMERA pulls back from the screen on which t movie is being projected. REVERSE INTO:
Over an audience of 40 or so computer students we read:
We pick out MILO CONNOR, watching keenly. He's 21: clear- eyed, alive, innocent. He sits with his best friend, TEDD CHIN, third-generation Chinese-American.
The coolest? Gary. He's like you or  me. If we happened t'be insanely  rich.
Some appreciative laughter in the auditorium. But behind  Milo, LARRY LINDHOLM squirms in his seat. He whispers:
Can we go?
For me? It's Seattle!
'Starting to get nauseated.
BRIAN BISSEL, in front of Milo, twists in his seat:
Do you mind?

Larry gets up. Two Outpost Recruiters, REDMOND PRICE, 31 (gray suit) and DANNY BAYLOR, 29 (Outpost '98 golf shirt) note the walkou Danny scans headshots in a Stanford Yearbook. (On-screen  behind them we see Seattle: night streets wet-down &  shimmering; Young People entering a club; Young People  climbing Mt. Shasta.) Finding Larry's picture, Danny poin out the name to Redmond, who shrugs: unconcerned.
Did anybody mention the beverages?
The double-doors swing open (over them, a plate reads: TH HEWLITT-PACKARD AUDITORIUM) and Larry comes out.

ALICE POULSON, a very pretty girl of 21 (more hiply dress than the geeks) searches the hall, reading the names over the doors (NEC Communications Classroom, Toshiba Computer Lab, Mitsubishi Classroom). She spots Larry.
Is it over?
They still have to give 'em  refreshments laced with mind-altering  drugs.
You are a fanatic.
'Gonna wait outside.
Tilting down the neo-classical edifice, we read the name  etched over the entrance: WILLIAM GATES COMPUTER SCIENCE  BUILDING. We find Larry and Alice sitting on the steps.
Alice? You gotta make him do the  start-up with Teddy and me.
"Make" him?
(thoughtfully) You know what I mean.
As we hear Larry speak, we cut back into:

The lights are on. Milo & Teddy stand by a table dressed Outpost bunting, laden with refreshments & giveaways:  mousepads, T-shirts, caps & books with the Outpost logo o them (a simple contour drawing of a frontier outpost). Wh most Students chat earnestly with Recruiters, Milo & Tedd load their plates with pizza and tortilla chips.
I'm not exactly worldly, but I'm the  Secretary of State next to him.
Milo puts some brownies on his plate.
And they're all throwing this --  stuff at him. Stock options. Pay  packages.
Spotting a book on the table, Milo picks it up.
I'm just screwed.
(that's not true) You know what he's like. He just  wants to work on stuff that's cool.
You don't wanna move, do you?
I can paint anywhere.
Larry looks at her: you didn't answer my question.
I'd like to stay here, yeah. And I  kind of think he should be with Teddy.
Milo and Teddy discuss the book almost joyfully. (We see page of code: utterly indecipherable.)
I mean, nobody else can follow what  they're talking about half the time.
(under Alice) 'Could be a condition-variable in  the locking code -- If it didn't seg  fault, first!
Maybe you shouldn't push it so hard.  About Outpost. No offense, you sound  insane.
I can't help it. I feel like they'd  do anything to keep their --

Anything? That's not even credible.  If he wants to go up there? To check  it out? I think you should encourage  him. (seeing Larry's  incredulity) It's his life. But everybody's  treating him like this -- valuable   object. You're hurting your own case.
Brian, already wearing one of the Outpost caps, effuses t Redmond.
He's my god. I hear he actually calls  recruits sometimes. Or is that an  Urban Legend?
Gary's running the biggest software  company in the world, Brian. He's  being harassed by the Justice  Department, and he's got a new baby.
Across the room, Milo (eating chips, perusing code) reach for a napkin but unwittingly grabs some bunting. It unrav in a long TP-like streamer -- just as Danny approaches,  peering at Milo's ID tag.
Milo? I'm Danny.
Oh hi.
He tries to sluff the paper off his hand; Danny holds out cell phone.
Gary would like to speak to you?
Milo and Teddy look at each other: right. But Danny looks like he means it. Milo's grin fades. He takes the phone.
...Hello?
Milo? Gary Boyd. I'm hoping you and  your friend can come up here. We've  made some amazing strides in digital  convergence. I'd love to show them  to you.
You would? Wow. When would we come? (he waits; he looks  up) 'Think he hung up.
Danny holds out two plane tickets, in 1st class folders.
Alice examines one of the tickets almost suspiciously.
But how does he know that's what you  guys're working on?
Larry, Teddy & Brian are at the table with Alice & Milo.  It's a student hang-out, with loud music.
All the companies know. The faculties  tell 'em. At the target schools.
In exchange for endowments. They  should just drop the pretense and  name the schools after 'em.
(to Teddy) I can't believe you refused a ticket!
My parents're already freaked-out  I'm staying here. 50 miles from  Chinatown.
Well maybe if you told 'em how much  money you'd be making -- (to Milo) You're going up there. Right?
I think you should go.
(amazed) You do?
I mean, it's your life.
As Alice predicted, Milo is pleased by Larry's remark.  "Empowered." Larry smiles conspiratorially at Alice.
In a tidy, playfully decorated room, Alice stirs in bed,  sees the space next to her is vacant.
Milo sits at a desk, thinking, agitated, in the dim light a PC. He looks up, sees Alice in the doorway.
I think I kind of lost it. I was  just so thrilled to be talking to  the richest, most powerful... 'Didn't  know I even cared about that stuff.
C'mon, how often do you talk to  somebody who's been on the cover of  Time. Three of four times.
She picks her way through geek clutter (motherboards, cod manuals, Coke cans) sits next to him.
A lot of what Larry says is true.  They just clone stuff, or reverse  engineer it, and everybody gets stuck  with their inferior version cause  they --
Then you've gotta ask him about that.
He looks at her: you've gotta be kidding.
It's important.
If he's really a bully, he won't cop  to it, anyway.
Bully? Are we talking about Gary  Boyd? Or your dad.
He doesn't deny it: she sees right through him.
When I was a kid? And he was moving  us all over the place? I spent all  my time writing stuff on Outpost  1.0. I thought Gary Boyd was the  greatest.
But he's not quite the same guy  anymore. Don't get your hopes too  high?
In the cabin, everybody types on a notebook but Milo. He  looks out the window expectantly: at the Seattle skyline.
Milo comes off the plane. Danny and Redmond greet him.
Redmond drives his black Lexus 85 m.p.h. Danny leans forw from the backseat.
'Couldn't convince Teddy to come?
He's pretty tight with his family.
We could move 'em up here.
He just likes to write code. He's  bummed there's so much secrecy and  competition, everybody trying to own  everything.
Who do you mean by "everybody."
Milo almost blushes. He makes an awkward segue.
So -- how far are we from the campus?
Oh we're not going to the campus.

Beyond a rocky beach, buildings are cunningly carved into wooded hillside. Glass walls are framed in rich wood. The main house is 28,000 sq. ft. Then there's the guest house pool building, reception hall, library...
Redmond pulls up. A discreet Guard in a Mr. Rogers cardig recognizes him. The gates swing open.
They pull up by a Lexus SUV with a baby seat. Another Man a cardigan stands in the open front door.
Who's that?
I think they call him the "Houseman."  'Cause "guard" sounds too weird.
Milo just sits there, eyeing the monumental residence.
Don't be nervous. The house is the  weirdest thing about him.
It's like he knows everybody expects  him to be this worldly, colorful  zillionaire. But he's just a guy who  likes software.
Milo and the Houseman cross a long room with a lake view. hear music by Satie. The Craftsman furniture and lamps ar custom-made. A Cezanne hangs on the wall.

head_text.subj: ANOTHER DEN-LIKE ROOM WITH A VIEW

text: There's a Craftsman crib here, stuffed animals, another  Cezanne. Even the toys seem arranged. They enter an
Have a seat. He won't be long.

Milo sits on a bench. He tries not to look, but his child hero is partly visible through a glass panel in the door: Gary (in a suit and tie) has an open American face. But  something goes on behind his pleasant features and self- possessed mien: his desire (or need) to solve the problem hand is so intense it makes him appear vexed -- even  vulnerable.
As Gary concentrates, two Outpost Senior Managers speak:  PHIL TATE, 40 (bald); and RANDY GRIMES, 36, (gray eyes).
We tried the big vaporware number,  Gary, it's no-sale.
Can we buy into their IPO? Or is  that a Justice Dept. problem?
There is no public offering. The guy  who wrote it joined some freakazoid  cult in San Luis Obispo. 'Wrote this  just to run their web site.
Gary speaks with precise hand gestures: settling the matt Phil and Randy gather their papers, and stand. They exit, nodding at Milo as they pass. Then Gary comes out.
Milo? Excuse the tie. I was on TV.
Milo is a little dazzled as they shake hands: such a fam- iliar face, such a big figure in his young life.
...That's okay.
Now New Age music plays. They move back through the same  room, but the Cezanne has been replaced by a Hieronymus B (bodies roiling in Hell). Milo is -- puzzled.
The house knows the paintings I like,  it knows my favorite music. Same for  anybody else who's in the system.
As they walk, Milo watches a Cezanne "original" digitally configure to a Bosch, brushstrokes and all.
Cool!
Would you like a Coke or something?
(too shy, too nervous) Oh. No thanks.
He opens a glass-doored refrigerator, scans a shelf with  rows of Snapples -- in alphabetical order.
When we started, I just hired my  smart friends. That was great. We  got a little bigger, I had to hire  smart strangers. Much harder.
He selects a Kiwi-Raspberry, they walk on.
Now I don't get to hire anybody. But  I know you're the guy to write  Skywire.

They enter. An entire wall is taken-up by a Bosch triptyc As Gary crosses to the other side of the room, Milo stand by a table covered in art books -- hundreds of them (Sout Chinoiserie, Roy Lichtenstein...)
You know a lot about art, I guess.
There's a rumor going around, maybe  you've heard it.
Gary heads back, carrying something spherical.
There's more to life than computers?  I'm looking into it.
Glancing down at the daunting display of books, Gary look vaguely afflicted. He mutters:
'Once I start looking into something.
Looking up now (and much more at ease) he holds up a shin detailed metal object: model satellite.

I've only shown this to three other  people. I bought 200, we've launched  12 so far. I keep the coordinates in  this room. (as Milo takes it,  carefully) It's left over from SDI. Reagan's  Star Wars technology? They orbit 426  miles up.
Low enough to relay internet traffic.
(he smiles: exactly) Among other things... We know  convergence is the real super-highway:  all the PC's, TV's, phones, etc.  linked together. Why cram it into a  cable if you can use the whole sky?
(turning the sleek  object) Skywire.
Milo and Gary peer at a monitor, side-by-side. Milo sips own Snapple now. Gary speaks his language.
The content filer has t'be written  into the media files so bits coming  off the satellite can be read by  multiplatforms. Really, omniplatforms.  Including whatever new hardware  emerges.
It needs a more object-oriented  language. This doesn't scale, does  it?

You'd have to start practically from  scratch. But this is all you'd be  working on. No marketing meetings,  no product seminars. We can't waste  the time. Half the Valley's working  on convergence. So're media  conglomerates, cable companies, phone  companies. 'Can't finish second,  Milo. There is no second... Now what  would you like to ask me?
Milo has a deer-in-the-headlights look.
...Ask you?
As they walk, Milo chides himself for his reticence. Gary seems to read his mind.
I know what people say, and not just  the Justice Department. We clone  ideas, inflict our second-rate  versions on the world, we haven't  done anything original since 1.0.
Milo's amazed by Gary's acuity. And his candor.
Do I think that's fair? No. I'd put  some of our apps up against anybody's.  But is there some truth to it?
They have come to a stop in a windowed entryway. Milo wat Gary keenly. Gary nods. He knits his brow.
When you get to a certain age, you  start wondering. About your legacy.  I doubt you even remember Outpost  1.0 --
I do!
(pleased) Yeah? I wanna feel like I did when I  wrote that. But I'm 42, that's 100  in cyber-years. I look at you and  see the things that got me here. (the furrows deepen) But somehow got away.

A block of floodlit "tract mansions," Taco Bell palaces o the Valley's newly rich. Milo & Alice cross a vacant lot where the lights twinkle below. Their '89 Honda Civic is  parked nearby. Milo is excited.
If my dad'd leveled with me like  that even once... The weird thing  is, my fantasy he could somehow be  like the old Gary? It's his fantasy,  too.
I think that's great, Milo. I do.
...But?
Didn't you visit the campus?
I forgot. That's why you have to  help me decide.
No way. You have this -- destiny.
C'mon, I wouldn't have a destiny  without you. My destiny would be  dying at 20. From eating --
Don't bring that up. Like a different  girlfriend would'd've let you die?
(shrugs) You saved my life in alot of ways.
He's sweet. She kisses him. He holds onto her.
It's not just Gary that makes you  wanna go there? 'Cause it's a big  place. You might not even see him  again.
He'd hate to think that's true. But he manages a smile.
I know.
The Honda is loaded with luggage and boxes, some of which are tied to the roof. Milo & Alice stow a final piece.
When's Brian coming for the TV?
Prob'ly waiting by the phone for  Outpost to call. We'll leave it for  him?
As they head back in, they see a Toyota park at the curb.
'Give you guys some time alone.
She continues inside. He waits, watches Teddy cross the  sidewalk to join him.
...You got my E-mail?
And your phone messages. You wanna  do what you do, it's not a crime.
Is that how Larry feels?
Uh. Not exactly.
A brown Buick parks behind Teddy's car. As they speak, a  rumpled, 50ish MAN in an off-the-rack suit gets out.
Wanted to say goodbye to him...
Hey, we got seed money for the  startup! A million-five!
Milo grins, he high-fives Teddy.

We rented a loft in Sunnyvale. (he gives Milo the  number) You know what's the bad part? We  can't talk about work anymore. We're  competitors! The venture capitalists  made us sign like 100 confidentiality  forms.
Outpost made me sign 1,000. 'Guess  we'll find out what else we have to  talk about. Life stuff.
They embrace. It's awkward, but it's heartfelt.
Milo enters, reading Teddy's phone number.
Guess what? They got their --
The rumpled Man sits on a radiator, watching CNN on a TV, the last remaining piece of furniture. Alice enters, hold a jam jar filled water, hands Milo a business card.
Milo, this is Mr. Barton from the  Justice Department. (gives Barton the  water) Sorry about the glass.
Milo reads the card: Lyle Barton, Asst. Prosecutor, DOJ,  Seattle Branch Office. Milo's a little spooked.
Don't worry, Milo. I'm here as a  friend. Or maybe a supplicant.
Right... What's that mean again?

Beggar. We're at a disadvantage with  Outpost. Our experts aren't as smart  as theirs. Sometimes we can't tell  which technologies pose the threat  of a monopoly. We need a really smart  guy to help us pick our fights. I'm  taking a shot in the dark, here. I  can offer you 32,000 a year, a Buick.  I'm hoping you've got a feeling it's  the right thing to do.
(fiddling with the  card) It's just -- I kind of feel the need  to do something with my ability.  Create something...
Like I said: shot in the dark.
Milo tries to give back the card.
If you see something there that rubs  you the wrong way? Do the right thing.
And he goes.
That took some fun out of --
We're not gonna let it.

She kisses him. They head out. We linger. On TV a graphic says: SAN LUIS OBISPO, CA: MASS SUICIDE - LIVE. Emergency Medical Personnel roll gurneys with bodies out of a new  Mediterranean mansion. Footage shows bodies (including a children) on bunkbeds, uniformly shod in black Nikes.
-- ingested the fatal mixture of  sedatives crushed in apple sauce.  According to the cult's eerily  professional website, it was "time  to move on..."
Crane past identical, low, steel & glass buildings, amid vast lawns & fir trees... Past a building under  construction... To find Redmond's Lexus, cruising.
Milo looks out the window, Redmond gives the tour:
There're 20 buildings, I mean not  counting the Gyms, the Day Care,  etc.
The Day Care is a Michael Graves-looking building with a cartoon-dog sculpture on its roof, ears cocked to the sky Teacher leads her little charges inside.
Gary's put millions in there. And  the people with kids? They're not  hotshot geeks, they're just payroll  clerks or whatever.
Two Men in suits, with briefcases, (conspicuous amid the  Geeks in jeans and T-shirts) enter Building #19.
You'll see alot of that: Department  of Justice goons snooping around.
The car pulls into a lot full of Miatas, BMW's, Boxters.
The logo is of inlaid stone. Redmond & Milo walk over it. Milo carries a box with some personal effects, including small painting. Redmond wears a photo I.D. tag.
So how'd you like the house?
His Snapples were in alphabetical  order.
(he laughs) Well, he micro-managed the company  till it got too big... (he opens the door) 'Guess he needs to micro-manage  something.
At the desk, a RECEPTIONIST looks up, stands to hang a  temporary ID pass around Milo's neck.
Milo, I'm Judith. Welcome!
Milo smiles. Redmond uses his magnetic swipe card on an i door (a security cam is at every door); he holds the door open for Milo.
They walk up a long carpeted hallway, past open offices w Geeks (mostly males under 30) sit at workstations.
Everybody has the same office, there's  no dumbass corporate hierarchy.
They pass a room in which Geeks play video games. Just ou it, a chubby programmer, DESI, sips a Diet Coke.
Get out while you can, dude!
Desi, Milo.
The guy who was at Gary's house?
He bows deep, with mock-obeisance. Milo blushes, Redmond  laughs, he snags Milo's elbow. They walk again, passing a service hall with a Civil Defense sign.
Best bomb shelters in America,  accessible from every building. You  gotta figure we're a major target,  right?
Up the hall, a young woman (LISA) is about to go into her office. She pauses half a second, looks at Milo, goes in. She's beautiful.
Whoa. Lisa actually looked at you.
As they pass her office, they look in: she's already at h workstation, studiously avoiding their gaze.
Every geek here's got a thing for  Lisa. But that's about the biggest  reaction she's had to anybody.
(shy, changing the  emphasis) She's a programmer?
Heavy graphical background, doing  design-interface for Skywire apps. (he all but winks) You'll be working with her.
I've got a girlfriend, remember?
Right. That's rare around here. You  know how nuns' re-married to Jesus?  'Posties are married to Outpost.
A handsome, modest office like all the others: workstatio whiteboard, window. They enter.
Here's your world. (pointing at the desk) Copy of Gary's book, also the audio  version, narrated by Gary.
Milo puts down his box, picks up the book: The Next Highw (Gary by a highway on its cover). As we look at it:
The card's encoded. Tells us who  came through the door and when.
In an office with a bank of monitors that play feeds from security cameras, BOB SHROT, 40, Head of Physical Securit issues Milo his swipe card. Redmond watches.
Unauthorized entries sound like this.
He drags the card through a sample slot, producing an  unbelievably loud, piercing EEEEEEEE. He shouts over it:
If you see a tailgater, report him.
Tailgater?
(kills the alarm) Somebody coming in on your swipe. (gives Milo a photo
You see somebody wandering around  without ID, it's your duty to  challenge him. I don't give a shit  if you're a stock-option billionaire.  If you don't challenge, I'll have  your butt.
He seems a little -- tense.
Geeks pull his chain cause he's non- tech. Ex-cop or something. They moon  cameras, or use ATM's as swipe cards.  The cameras're our real security so  he's a little demoralized.
As they walk, Milo watches two Hardhats roll a spool of f optic cable into the building under construction.
What're they building?
#21. Way behind schedule. It's top- secret, but everybody knows it's a  digital broadcast space. They see  the dishes on top, the fiber optics  going in.
Gary's not into fiber optics. He's  betting everything on the satellites.
You wanna survive in the software  business, you cover your bets... I  gotta say, this is the weirdest car  anybody ever requested.
They approach a 1990 Deux Chevaux, cheap but charming.
Oh, right. Your girlfriend's an  artist.
Blond wood, smoked glass -- a room as sleek as the Geeks lunch here are nerdy. Milo and Redmond push trays.
I phoned her at your hotel, told her  about our corporate housing options.  She sounds neat.
Lisa's at a table, looking at Milo. When their eyes meet, she busies herself, placing the plates back on her tray.
...She is. (turning away from  Lisa) She is!
Lisa passes behind them, smiles fleetingly at Milo. At a  table, Randy and Phil note the "interaction." Meantime:
'Might be some friction on the  domestic front. You're expected you  to put in ridiculous hours. People've  accused us of breaking up  relationships to get their undivided  attention.
He laughs.
Lisa moves swiftly up the hall. She looks up it and down (making sure no one's looking) before ducking into
She goes to the box on Milo's desk (his personal effects) starts rooting through it.
Redmond and Milo have eaten; Redmond stacks their plates.
Your counselor'll fill you in on  everything else. That's who you'll  be working with almost daily.
Milo has fed the old Skywire disks into his machine. He r a complicated screen.
Busy?
Milo looks up. It's Gary. Milo is thrilled.
No! Just waiting for my counselor to  come by and introduce himself.
Okay. I'm Gary.
Milo's smile deepens. Gary notices the small painting (by Alice) hanging on the wall. He stares at it.
'Think I should buy some originals?
...Do I?
Somebody said I'm just another  Philistine. With reproductions.
That's insane. You're ahead of your  time.
That's what I told her. My wife.
Milo colors as Gary drags a second chair in front of the  screen; didn't realize he was contradicting Mrs. Boyd.
'Thinks I'll be less of a control  freak if I have a hobby. 'Just gives  me something else to obsess about...
Milo smiles as Gary sits down, studies the screen.
Anything we can salvage from the old  code before you start fresh?
Milo can't quite get over: Gary's his counselor.
Uh, might be one or two things.
Two awe-struck Geeks see Gary through the window.
He's been in there like an hour.
Shit.
Could work with a new switch. There  may be a few more things hidden.

Don't spend too much time searching.  You ever vetted somebody's old code  before? (when Milo shakes his  head) It's a different skill. Stay close  to the surface. The best-hidden  secrets are in plain sight. You know  the best place to hide a leaf, right? (when Milo shakes his  head) In a tree.
We're in an old (empty) Craftsman house. Through a front  window, we see Alice lead Milo up a path. As they enter:
...The corporate condos were as  romantic as they sound.
Milo's grinning as he takes in the house.
Windows give onto a garden with a small studio. Milo's st beaming, Alice is pleased. Till he says:
You know he's never been anybody's  counselor before?
Milo! What about --?
She gestures at what she hopes will be their home.
Oh, It's great. It's great! (they start to kiss,  but:) 'Think I should tell him I learned  everything using 1.0? Maybe I could  show him one of my early programs.
She pulls him back into the kiss.

1.) MILO types intently in his office. 2.) GARY sits with MILO at his desk, discussing code. Pan the window; we see a different pair of awed Geeks. 3.) Milo & Alice read in bed. He's reading Gary's book. 4.) MILO shows GARY one of his early programs, written on 1.0.: it's simple-looking, with some childish writing scr on it. Gary seems touched.
Two DOJ AGENTS depose Gary. (A video-cam records his answ Two Outpost LAWYERS sit next to him. One of the Agents is reading from a document:
"Infotek's urgent need to license  Outpost Office is such that we can  use it as a tool in the current  negotiation." (looks up) When you wrote the word "tool," what'd  you mean by it?
Gary studies his copy of the E-mail. He looks vexed.
I don't remember.
What d'you think you meant by it?
I'm confused. Am I supposed to  speculate under oath?
The Agent shifts in his seat. We get an idea of Gary's  negotiating skill (making the other party look unreasonab while offering nothing).
Since you didn't have an answer to  that question, Mr. Boyd --
("confused" again) Didn't I? Have an answer? "I don't  remember."
The Agents confer. Gary sees Phil, looming outside the op door. One of the Agents sees him, too. He doesn't try to  hide his annoyance:
Did you wanna take a break, Mr. Boyd?
Gary takes a manila envelope from Phil, opens it.
Your protege's moving so fast we can  barely keep up with him.
Gary reads the page from the envelope: computer code.
This is good. Who did it?
'Start-up not 50 miles from here.  Kid's on Prozac.
Maybe we should all get on it.
Milo stares at his screen, frustrated. Gary enters.
How's it going?
Maybe I'm going too fast.
(sharply; incredulous) Too fast? At least four companies're  on the verge of workable convergence  systems, Milo, they --
Catching himself, Gary trails off. He sits down, exhales.
Even when I had a hand in every aspect  of the company I knew the one thing  you can never control is somebody's  creative process.

Gary seems sincerely contrite. (He needn't be: Milo just  wants to please him. Besides: Milo sees he'd like to stop obsessing about convergence, to be a "worldly zillionaire engrossed in his hobbies; but, after all, what could be m engrossing than Skywire?)
It's okay. Really.
(reaching into his  pocket) Take a look at this. Slightly  different approach.
Reading the page Gary got from Phil, Milo knits his brow.
You did this -- overnight?
You're making me young again.
PAN OFF a TV, where local news footage shows a mangled,  smoking BMW, post-wreck, on a lonely nocturnal highway.
...A graduate of MIT, he was on the  antidepressant Prozac, and had been  warned not to drink and drive. (Etc.)
Lisa watches the news report, knowingly.
Lisa heads up the hall, carrying a CD-ROM.
Milo's typing.
Milo?
He looks. He stands.
Lisa.
You know my name.
You know mine.
You're famous around here.
(winces) I'm getting a teacher's pet rep.
I wouldn't worry about it. You've  gotta figure most people around here  were their teachers' pets.
...Were you?
We moved around so much I barely  knew my teachers.
Me too! Were you an Army brat or  something?
...Something like that. Yeah.
Didn't mean to pry. I just have this  theory. Some of us who got to good  at this? We were -- escaping  something.
This seems to jolt her. She pales a little. What a myster girl. But this only adds to her allure.
Did I say something?

No, I know what you mean. I used to  spend my life wishing people could  be like computers. Least they make  sense. Sometimes you think they've  betrayed you. Like a person would.  But then you see, no, you just missed  a step. You can go back and make it  all work.
This strikes a deep chord with Milo, all of it.
I used to wish that. All the time.
They're looking at each other: he gets self-conscious.
(re: the CD-ROM) What've you got there?
Graphical interfaces. For Skywire?  I'm s'posed to coordinate with you.
Show me.

They sit. As she inserts the disk, he finds himself looki at her. On the screen, the frontier outpost we know as th logo appears. It's struck by a bolt from the sky. The out comes alive with light, music, movie-images through its  windows, a ringing phone. Finally, the word SKYWIRE burns into it. It's neat, she's really good.
Cool!
Yeah? I ran it for lots of platforms,  ranging from the narrowest bandwidth  to --
Simultaneously, they reach for the mouse. Their hands tou They look at each other. Something happened.
...Sh-Show me the next one.
She nods, manipulates the mouse. He stares at the screen  strenuously, fighting the impulse to stare at Lisa.
Gary's SECRETARY types as Milo enters. She smiles at him.
Have a seat. He's with someone, but  I know he wants to see you.
Gary's face is red. The two Lawyers who sat in on his  deposition are with him again.
Because we bundled it, the judge is  threatening to enjoin the whole --
I'm confused, Ted.
Gary has used the phrase before, but the pretense of  ingenuousness is gone; it's witheringly condescending.
Didn't you tell me they'd be Chapter  12 by the time they could hope to  enjoin? I'm very confused, because  you said they'd be ready to settle.

Milo hears Gary yelling behind the closed door. It's  indecipherable, but we discern an enraged "bullshit!" Mil flips through a copy of Wired, trying to ignore it. The  Lawyers come out, passing swiftly, rather grimly.
Go on in. (when Milo looks  dubious) He's always happy to see you.
Agitated, Gary rather compulsively lines-up the papers, p etc. on his desk; he barely hears the knock at the open  doorframe.
Milo. What's up?
Well -- you sent for me.
Right... Right.
Still distracted, he finds a page of code on his desk, gi it to Milo. Once again, Milo marvels.
You really wrote this just today?
(dark, unsmiling) What're you implying.
(taken aback) Nothing!
Their eyes are locked. Gary blinks, sags into his chair.
Everything I do is under scrutiny.  The questions they ask, trying to  make anything strategic look sordid. (knits his brow) I'm confused. Doesn't everybody in  business try to get ahead?
(uncomfortable) I'm sure.

The purpose of this company isn't to  destroy our competitors any more  than the purpose of living is to  breath. But the software business is  binary: you're a zero or a one. Being  obsessive isn't a crime. It's a  character trait.
Milo just wants to get out. He studies the code to hide h discomfort. Gary watches him.
It scales, don't you think?
Definitely.
He smiles. For the first time it looks forced.
A youthfully upscale place, a converted red-brick warehou Alice looks great. The Waiter pours wine.
This feels fairly grown up, I'd say.
Milo smiles (again it looks forced) raises his glass.
To our new life. (she's looking at him) ...What's wrong?
That's what I need to ask you. (when he says nothing) You know you can't keep anything  from me.
He gave me some new code-fixes this  morning. I said, "Did you really do  this just today?" Cause I was  impressed. He said "What're you  implying?"
She just looks at him. He grows a little defensive:
It's the way he said it. Just the  way my dad did, when he was caught  in a lie. That's how you knew you  were onto something ugly.
(just confused) What would it mean, anyway? If he  didn't write it?
That's what I'm asking myself. Does  he have some genius stowed away? Why  not let him write Skywire. (upset) 'Not saying it makes sense.
A Busboy leaves a basket of rolls. Glum, preoccupied, Mil takes one without looking, brings it to his lips --
Milo!
He looks at Alice, looks at the roll, blanches.
I'm so stupid.
He throws the roll back into the basket.
He's your boss. He's not your --
(he's nodding) I know, I know.
If you can't deal with him on that  basis, you better get a new counselor.
(the very idea hurts) Isn't that -- extreme?
What's extreme is what that ER doctor  said when he pumped your stomach.  Eat another sesame seed and that's  it.
We see the rolls: covered in seeds.
I mean, if one little comment from  Gary is gonna upset you this much --
You're right. It's -- a working  relationship. Don't know what I was  expecting.
He smiles. But his heart's not in it. She hates to see hi suffer. She picks up her glass.
C'mon. Let's do the toast?
Milo sits alone, marking up pages of code as he eats. He  doesn't notice Lisa, standing with her tray.
Did you wanna be alone?
No. Please.
He indicates she should sit.
They just pushed up the schedule on  Skywire apps. How fast are you going?
"There is no second place." Plus  every time I get jammed-up, Gary has  an inspiration. (looks at her, curious) Is it like that with your counselor?
Mine's not the CEO. He barely  remembers to take a shower.
Right, right. But does he ever just,  like, hand you code?
Maybe once. I re-wrote it, anyway.
(he smiles) You're compulsive.
Mmm-more like -- I have a little  trouble. Trusting people.
Why's that?
Long story. Not that interesting.
She smiles charmingly to cover whatever she's feeling. Th more enigmatic she is, the more intrigued he is.
Milo and Lisa walk, eat ice cream out of paper cups with  Outpost logos. They laugh. We go nearer.
So, when you were talking about  wishing people were more like  computers. Was that then? Or now?
Then and now. (when he looks at her) But not right now.
She maintains eye contact. Her meaning is clear.
Milo!

Milo turns, sees Brian (Stanford classmate, Outpost zealo give an envelope to a Guard at the door of #20; he trots  over to Milo, who is as flustered as another guy might be having been found in bed with a girl.
Just dropped off a resume. Almost  got in the front door.
He looks at Lisa, back to Milo, wondering why he isn't be introduced.
You're living here?

'Thought if I relocated it could  help my case. I'm writing programs  for the local public access station.  Where any whack-job with 100 bucks  gets his own show? God, does it suck. (gives him a business  card) Can you help me?
Sure, I'll see what I can do.
Seeing how flushed Milo is, Brian thinks he must have  blundered in on something. He starts to back away.
Well I parked illegally. See y'later?
(watching Brian go) 'Forgot to introduce you. (a beat) I have a girlfriend.
That's great. I -- didn't know.
She saved my life.
The station is closed. Milo's car is parked, empty.
How's it going down there?
We find him, in an illuminated phone booth.
I've been hacking for five night's  straight, I'm really making headway.
A funky space, posters on the wall, a red Stanford pennan rubber trees at either end of his desk.
But these, like, White Supremacists  trashed my office, last week.
What?!
On the wall beyond Teddy the word GOOK (in blood red) has been covered over with paint but still bleeds through.
They're in the neighborhood. They  usually hassle Vietnamese grocers.
Jesus, Teddy.
I'm cool. They didn't touch the  machine. Or my disks. Probably didn't  know what they were. So, you a Moonie  yet? (he waits) Milo?
I met this girl.
What? Come on. Is it serious?
I don't know.
Did you tell Alice?

No! I keep thinking it'll go away.  But there's this -- connection. She's  been hacking since she was little,  she had to move around a lot. Plus I  see her every day, we're working on  the same program. She's -- beautiful.
A beautiful geek? I don't wanna sound  paranoid, or like a pig, but what're  the chances?
What d'you mean?
I dunno. I guess Larry's got me  totally suspicious of that place.
What does that mean?
Milo, geeks don't have two  girlfriends. Most don't have one.
I didn't plan this.
Through a window, we watch Milo traverse the quad.
What'd the girl say?
There may be a little less trust  after your outburst.
We are
Gary turns back inside, where Phil reads Milo's new code.
Hasn't affected his work, though.
Nothing does. Still. I want him to  like me.
Phil is confused by Gary's sincerity; so is Gary.
Desi and another Geek watch in astonishment: Gary walks M to his car, his arm circled over Milo's shoulder. He seem to be -- apologizing.
Milo comes eagerly up the path: can't wait to tell Alice  what just happened. He enters -- pulls up short. Alice is waiting for him. She's white.
...What's wrong?
She doesn't know how to say it.
What!
Teddy was killed last night.
What're you -- what?
It was a hate crime.
Milo is staggered. She moves to him...
I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.
He hangs onto her, for support.
Establish the funky building, vestiges of police tape on door, a limo and many cars parked out front.
A mixture of Teddy's relatives and Computer Friends have  gathered. In the BG, Teddy's Dad weeps volubly.
Teddy's brother, NELSON, shows Milo the workspace: red  Stanford pennant, rubber trees on the desk. Milo, in a su peers at the painted-over epithet on the wall.
They trashed his hard disk, all his  back-ups. Nothing's left.
They caught the guys?
Nelson shows Milo a San Jose Mercury: mugshots of two ski headed Aryan Nations Members in their 20's.
It's an airtight case. They found  the weapon with Teddy's blood on it  and their fingerprints. They'd been  arrested twice for beating-up Asians.  How come they weren't in jail?
Milo unpins a picture of himself & Teddy from a board.
He told me about the break-in. He  didn't seem to take it that seriously.
You guys don't take anything seriously  do you? That's not on a hard drive?
Milo is stung by this. Alice appears in the doorway.
Nelson? Your mom wants you. It's  time to go to scatter the ashes.
Milo is pinning the picture back up. The pushpin falls to the floor, he kneels to retrieve it. On the floorboards, sees a thin, shiny plastic filament. He picks it up.
I didn't know he was working with  fiber optics.
But when he looks up, Nelson's gone.
We gotta go too, honey.
As he heads out with Alice, he unthinkingly stuffs the  filament in his suit pocket.
A raw beautiful bluff. The sea stretches to infinity behi a smaller group of Mourners. A LAY MINISTER intones the L Prayer.
Milo approaches Larry with trepidation. Larry nods, it's  okay. They hug each other. They walk slowly back toward t cars.
I know you lost all his work. Maybe  I could come down here and --
You are naive. Look at your employment  contract: you can't work anywhere  else in this field for at least few  years. (he smiles sadly) Not that I don't miss you.
Just thought his work should go on.
He was on the verge of something,  too. He was gonna show us the next  day. He said "The answer's not in  the box, it's in the band." Know  what it means?
It's only meaningful when you've got  40,000 lines of code to back it up.
Man, could he write code. Totally  elegant. He had his own style.
Those really weird, short lines.
They smile. For a moment, they've brought Teddy back to l Alice comes up from behind, to fetch Milo.
Take good care of this guy.
Arriving for work, Milo sees Outpost flags at half mast.
As Milo comes up the hall, Lisa is standing there. We get the feeling she's been waiting for him.
You okay?
He looks at her, perhaps hearing Teddy's words ("what're chances?"). He nods, moves on. She watches him head up th hall.
Milo types. There is a rapping on the doorframe. Gary.
I heard what happened.
Were the flags for Teddy?
Gary nods. Spontaneously Milo stands, hugs Gary.
Had you talked to him much lately?
Just once. 'Guess I was worried we  didn't have anything to talk about,  since work was off-limits. Non- disclosure.
Did you?
Talk about work? Never!
I meant did you find other stuff to --
Oh. Yeah.
You've been coming in early.
It helps. Alice said it would help.  To focus on something. (a little guilty) 'Don't know what I'd do without her.
Milo sits on the couch, in dim light. Alice comes in.
You okay? (sits by him, holds  him) I miss him, too.
Milo eats alone. Through the window, he sees Lisa inside. She's eating alone, too. Gary comes trotting up.
Milo?
He is unclasping a manila envelope; he takes pages out.
Wow. You must have 20,000 lines of  code there...
34,000. But they're real short lines.  'Just came out that way.
Seeing Gary's code, Milo knits his brow: it must be sort like -- Teddy's.
Been thinking about the push mechanism  in the handler. And it came over me:  it's in the wrong place.
(an uncertain smile) The wrong place?
The answer's not in the box. It's in  the band.

Milo's smile freezes. As he stares at Gary, we zoom with reverse dolly so that the background retreats queasily bu Gary remains dominant in frame. For Milo, it feels like t very ground is going out from under him. Gary continues to explain, pointing at lines of code. And Milo pretends to listen. But he can't even make out the w Gary speaks -- he hears only a jumble of echoes. Milo nods mechanically; he wants to scream. Or run. He  perceives, amid the echoes, that Gary is standing, smilin saying "See you later." And he's gone. Milo touches the pages, like some talisman of Teddy.
Milo? You okay?
It strikes him she always shows up at these moments. He  gathers his wits before looking up.
Gotta go home. 'Think I ate something.

Pulling out of the lot, Milo seizes the car phone. He hit HOME on the speed-dial. Gets a busy signal. Rings off. He about to press re-dial when he sees the Outpost logo bran on the receiver. He throws it down like it's contaminated.
Middle-of-the-day sounds: chirping birds, school children Milo pulls to the curb at a bad angle.
He fumbles with his keys. When he gets inside:
Alice? Alice!
He moves into the bedroom. He sees her through the window painting in the studio.
He stands outside the studio. Waits for her to look up. S does. She smiles. Then she sees something's wrong. He wai for her to come out here, where it's safe to speak.
He paces, agitated. She watches him. She's skeptical, but doesn't want to appear unsympathetic.
Are you saying you think they had  something to do with his death? Nelson  said it was an airtight case.
I don't know what I'm saying. Maybe --  maybe they hired those guys.
I can't see Outpost putting its  reputation in the hands of people  like that.

I don't know! I just know it was  Teddy's code. All these ideas flying  in from everywhere. You know how he  says "Any kid working in his garage  can put us out of business?" It's  like they know what every kid's doing.
They hack into people's programs?
Nobody does work like this on-line.  It's in your PC, or in a mainframe.  Self-contained. They'd have to be,  like, watching people. Physically. (he freezes) Oh Jesus.

Milo's at the closet, rummaging among the clothes hanging there. Alice comes up behind him. He finds his suit jacke He digs in one pocket, then another. He finds the fiber o strand (from Teddy's floor). Shows it to her.
(almost silently) It's a camera.
They've trooped back outside. She's worried she's indulgi his paranoia.
It isn't a broadcast studio. It's --  a surveillance post or something.  That's why they have the dishes on  top.
You're scaring me. I think we should  just go.
Go where? You can't get away from  people like this.
"Like this?" It's Gary you're talking  about.
(it really hurts) You think I don't know that?
Milo. Why would he --
How should I know? "Solving a  problem," I guess. Or needing to  control everything. I don't know. (can't think about it) I've gotta get in there.
Even if all this were true. There're  20 other buildings. All of them filled  with computers and --
It's the only one with dishes on the  roof. The studio's a front. That's  why they keep postponing its opening. (muttered, obsessive) ...gotta get in there.

Milo, you told me those DOJ Agents  are all over the place. How could  they hope to hide a surveillance  post? (as he mulls this) And how can you get in there, anyway?  With the cameras and the swipe cards --
I can't just walk away!
You can't just walk in, either.
They stop the construction work at  six or seven. The parking lot's mostly  clear by two or three in the morning.  Even the early Geeks don't get there  before five.
Is it two? Or is it three? Have you  ever really noticed?
He knows what she's saying: he's unqualified for this, a  space-cadet. She tries to hold him. But he wriggles away.
No! I can't just keep my head in the  sand. That's how I got into this  mess.
He paces, he thinks. She watches him, worried.
I know how to get in there. But you've  gotta help me.
(scared, reluctant) ...Whaddo I do?
So you believe me?
She can't lie. She shakes her head.
Just tell me what to do.
Standing at his window, Milo can see #21. Workers in Hard come out of it, carrying lunchboxes. Milo holds a small  writing pad. He notes the time.
Alice parks in front of a drugstore. As she gets out of t car, she looks around uneasily.
Alice is at the counter, buying a wind-up alarm clock.
Milo watches a car pull out of the parking lot, leaving o one or two others. He writes down the time.
Alice is at the counter, among children and mothers,  purchasing a chemistry set.
He watches a SECURITY GUARD (DELBERT) go into #21 on his  rounds, notes the time: 3:45 AM.

Alice, wearing dishwashing gloves, ties the alarm clock t small Tupperware container with copper wire. Milo (wearing latex gloves) is at the sink, mixing chemic from the toy chemistry set. Alice approaches with the  container affixed to the clock. As she holds it out Milo  pours the mixture into it.
OVER BLACK we hear ticking. The screen lightens to show:
Milo's alarm clock is set for 11:00. It sits amid mops an cleaning products.
Milo stands in the open door of a refrigerator, as if  searching for a soda. He's looking up the hall, waiting f someone. He consults his watch. 10:53.
Come on.
Here comes a GUARD; he nods to Milo as he passes. The Gua opens a door with his card. Milo rushes through the door the Guard's swipe -- "tailgating."
Sir, you gotta use your own -- (noticing) Where's your ID?
Milo cops an attitude. He's not completely convincing.
Do you know who I am?
It's my job, I gotta --
(he's getting better) The kind of stock options I'm sitting  on?
Bob Shrot, the ex-cop in charge of physical security, loo up as the Guard escorts Milo into the room.
The bomb explodes. The blast is tiny but loud (glass clea bottles ring; plastic bottles moan).
Milo sits, watches Shrot encode a new card for him, findi his info on a terminal. On a monitor behind Shrot, Milo s Programmers being ushered out of the building.
Every geek has to try this once to  show me how smart he is --
ANOTHER GUARD rushes in.
There was an explosion in a Y-sector  closet, we're evacuating the whole  sector.
Shrot comes to his feet, grabs a holster (with gun) off a shelf. Milo, looking flummoxed, stands.
Un-nh, can't wander around without  ID now. Just park your ass in that  chair.
Milo sits. Shrot goes out with the Guard.
Whole place reeks of fuckin' ammonia.
Milo moves quickly to the wall, reads a chart with the Gu Schedule, runs his finger down it til he finds the name o the Guard on the 3 AM shift: DELBERT, KEN.
Guards open closet doors, shine their flashlights.
Milo has moved to Shrot's seat. He's encoding a fresh car with Ken Delbert's information.
Panning off the civil defense sign we find Shrot standing a closet, examining a piece of the alarm clock.

Milo is at work, bringing up schematic screens, diagnosin the system with his unique concentration. Panning to the window, we see the evacuated Programmers  enjoying themselves on the lawn. It's a rare, exciting ev they jump around, miming explosions.
Shrot and the Guard collect pieces of the bomb out of the debris, puts them in a tray.

Milo brings up the screen that controls the #21 cameras. the monitors, he sees nothing very interesting: a hallway room under construction... He pulls down a menu. RECORDING is highlighted. He clicks PLAYBACK. The image hardly changes, but a Guard wanders  through. He types, the tape rewinds (the Guard moves  backwards). He finds a neutral spot (showing an empty  hallway), stops the tape.
Gary, Randy & Phil approach Shrot; Gary stares at him.
What is it?
Not much. Glorified cherry bomb.  Right by the civil defense sign?  Some geek's idea of irony. I been  saying we need a camera in this hall.
There's nothing in this hall.  Someone's pulling your chain, as  usual.
(thinking aloud) Unless it's a diversion. Milo's in  my office. He was tailgating, so I --
Gary explodes, with incredulity.
Milo? Try to have a clue. Try to  think.
Gary strides off. Shrot feels unfairly maligned.
That kid's the great white hope.
I could get it out of him.
You're not listening.
Randy and Phil head up the hall. Shrot watches them. Even his "intellectual superiors" are convinced of Milo's  innocence, he isn't. He walks swiftly back toward his office. Then he runs.
Milo reads a warning message. DOWNLOADING PLAYBACK STREAM

head_text.subj: RECORD CYCLE WILL CAUSE BIT OVERLOAD. DO YOU WISH TO PROC

text: Y/N. He types Y. The glitch freezes the tape (we see it lock into place): shows the empty hallway.

They've let the Programmers back in. They head up the hal as Shrot heads down it. He pushes past them gruffly. He knows he's enhancing his Neanderthal image (they make  cracks) but he's more interested in obeying his instinct.
Milo immobilizes another camera in #21... and another.
Shrot rounds the corner. His office is in view, now.
Milo, at the keyboard, closes up windows, one by one.
Shrot is back, he has only to round the corner to see Mil We assume his POV as he does so: Milo sits in the chair where Shrot left him.
Everything okay?
Pan off the clock (3:20 AM) to find Milo at his desk, loo at the clock with a certain dread. It's time.

Milo walks the path between the two buildings, fiddling  nervously with the dummied swipe card. Hearing footfalls behind him, he whirls: it's a Geek lopi to his car. He smiles. Milo smiles: waits, walks on. Nearing #21, Milo looks around, making sure no one else i around. His POV (panning): A Programmer works late, visib through a lighted window in #20... The dog sculpture with cocked ears sits atop the Day Care, its quizzical express seeming to wonder what Milo is up to... The Geek he just racing by on foot now pulls out of the parking lot in his James Bond BMW... Milo arrives at the entrance. Heart pounding, he brings t card to the slot. Will he trigger that awful alarm? He slides the card, the door clicks.
He enters: concrete floor, unpainted walls, construction  lights. At the inner door he looks up at the camera.
that shows us where Milo stands, minus Milo. Widen:
A GUARD packs up his stuff, getting ready to go home. The new guard, KEN DELBERT enters.
How's it goin'?
(shaking out his cup) Big night. Switched from tea to  coffee. Brought new meaning to my  work.
Yeah? Maybe I'll start my rounds  with #21 tonight.
You are a wild man.

Milo moves up a hall with unpainted walls, bare floors,  unconnected wires. The only illumination is from construc lights on the concrete floor. Opening doors, he sees: Bare rooms. Wall plates ready to receive electrical equip bundles of wire hanging out. In other words: the building as advertised, so far.
Delbert comes out with his flashlight, heads across the c swept path that leads to #21.

Milo nears a set of double-doors at the end of the hall. hears a low ominous hum from within. Convinced he's found something, he quickens his pace. He's about to swipe his  card when a beam of light bounces along the wall. He presses himself into an alcove. Through a chink in the unfinished wall he sees: Delbert come in the front door. His rounds consist of shi his torch up at the cameras, making sure the red lights a on. He walks right past Milo (who doesn't breath). Delbert swipes open the double doors, leans in: the hummi gets louder. ON MILO: pressing himself into the alcove. Delbert turns around, heads back down the hall... exits t building. Milo waits a beat before heading to the end of the hall.  Using the card, he enters

A studio-to-be, architectural touches like soffits framed but not plaster-boarded. The portentous hum comes from ar a corner. He approaches, convinced the answer lies here.  Clearing the wall he sees: A squat emergency generator sitting on the floor, powerin construction lights. Something you'd buy at Sears.
Through infra-red binoculars we see Milo come out, lookin left and right, to make sure he hasn't been observed.
Well. Now he knows: nothin' in there.
We are
Randy turns back into the room, where Phil is sifting thr papers spread over a coffee table.
Maybe he'll get back to work.
Speaking of which...
Yeah, yeah.
Randy pulls the blinds shut, joins Phil.
From a high angle, we track Milo, as he walks along the p to a bench. The camera passes briefly behind a dark objec in the foreground (dog sculpture) as we track him.

Milo sags onto the bench. He stares out, perplexed, suffe Then he knits his brow. He seems to be studying -- the gr Or rather the shadow stretched out in front of him: the  looming silhouette of the dog atop the Day Care. He stands up, turns around. REVERSE ON: The whimsical canine. Push toward it's ears cocked to the sky... Then toward a single ear, framed by fur-brown conc but with a smooth, concave inner surface of enamelled met satellite dish.
(muttering) ...in a tree...
At the entrance, Milo applies the swipe-card.
He steps in on colorful carpeting, amid balls & tricycles Kid's artwork hangs on the wall. He moves through this ro into the

20 screens glow. They hang suspended over a wide, ringed  table, a chair at each keyboard. Indeed, Gary has spared expense for the toddlers: they're flat, sleek, digital  screens. At the moment, they show colorful, childish cont drawings that say WHERE I WANNA WORK (e.g.: a spaceship). There are a dozen more screens on tables at the perimeter the room showing screensavers (eg: angelfish swimming). Milo moves slowly around the table, studying the screens. Not surprisingly, most of the WHERE I WANNA WORK drawings are of desks or tables with computers. Tracking just ahead of Milo, we get to a screen that show workstation with a red pennant on the wall, a rubber plan at each end of a desk. Even in contour form it's -- famil Milo passes it. And comes back to it. Staring at it, he sits. He begins typing. [The drawing st occupies the screen, but in a window he's brought up at t bottom, there is dense, DOS-looking code.] He types furio numbers, symbols, backslashes. Whatever he's trying to do a challenge even to him. He deletes lines, begins anew, h frustration evident. As he works through the layers of code, the pixels on the screen start to fill in. The contour lines slowly dissolv into a live broadcast image of Teddy's workstation in  Sunnyvale (eerily empty, now). When all the pixels have fallen into place, Milo hears CL CLICK CLICK CLICK CLICK from every direction, as all the  screens in the room fill in with live broadcast images. A of them show variations on a theme: A workstation seen by a camera over-the-shoulder of a  programmer (if he were present). The stations are of vari shapes and sizes, but in each case we have an unobstructe view of screen & keyboard. At this hour, few programmers present. One guy has fallen asleep, his head on a desk. A Japanese Geek is hard at work: it's day there.
Phil and Randy work at the coffee table.
Did you download Corey? In San Jose?
Damn. 'Have to go back over there. (he stands, stretches) Be so much easier if we could walk  in the front door.
You don't look anything like a three- year-old.

Milo works the keyboard. Again, the code gets dense and  obscure as he goes deeper. He succeeds in calling-up a  graphical interface. Among the menus he can choose from a TARGET SCHOOLS, PD UPLOADS, RX UPLOADS. He clicks Target Schools, a menu shoots down (Berkeley, C Tech, etc.). He clicks Stanford, then Chin, Teddy. Two wi open. In one, there is a video stream of Teddy winning an award in the Gate's Bldg. In the other, uploaded police v stenciled SUNNYVALE PD) of the White Supremacists whose m shots we saw in the San Jose Mercury; they're being  interrogated. In the first window, Teddy's image dissolves into a handh crime-scene video (marked SV-PD) of a ransacked grocery s "DIE GOOK!" is painted on a wall. Milo looks confused: so "narrative" is unfolding, but it remains obscure without  audio. He types some more. In the bottom window, he brings up convoluted text regard the audio. About the only phrases we can understand are:  "Audio Block ON" and "Hardware Requirement: Magnetic Filt Type PBX-R17." His eyes cast about the room for some suitable hardware  substitute. He digs in his shirt pocket. He takes out his swipe card, studies it. He casts about some more, till he sees some kids' safety scissors in a jar.
Randy whistles as he heads up the hall. Arriving at the d with the Civil Defense sticker, he swipes his card.

On-screen, long-lens footage shows a low building; the Ar Nations suspects come out of it. A still photo appears in the 2nd window: a steel hasp. Milo's eyes are narrowed: what am I seeing? Meantime, he reaching under the table where he has removed a plate fro the mainframe terminal, exposing hardware within. He has trimmed the swipe card to size and is wedging its  magnetic strip into a metal slot. He wiggles the card. We hear an eerie fibrillation, which flattens into the voice a serene, eminently sane female:
-- run this methamphetamine lab known  to Federal Authorities, per ND 47,  from which we removed the implement,  fingerprints intact.

Crime-scene video streams in now stenciled FBI by the  time/date). A handheld camera pans a blood-spattered wall then shows a mutilated Asian murder victim. (All of this  footage is made even eerier by the jerky glitches always  present in streaming video, and its sinister graininess.)
FBI footage, procured by ND 47, shows  the aftermath of an Aryan Nations'  killing in Denver. Note the evidence  of torture, which is typical.
Milo pales as he realizes he is watching a primer on how  racial killings are done. He hears a creaking noise behind him, and whirls. It's the classroom hamster, on his wheel.
Still whistling, Randy descends some metal stairs, enters vast bomb shelter (canned foods, etc.)
Milo has tapped into his own file: footage of him lecturi at Stanford (as an RA), pointing to a whiteboard.
-- complete immersion in code-writing  renders him both unobservant and  suggestible [click]. On two occasions  he went truant from classes to attend  Comix Conventions.

The audio crackles and drops out again. Milo's eyes narro he sees video of Alice, sitting on a folding chair, speak to someone. She has a harder look, pulls on a Marlboro. What's he seeing? He wiggles the jerry-rigged hardware al urgently, till the narration crackles back on:
-- Rebecca P, a Connecticut art stu-  dent facing Federal drug charges,  whose records were supplied to us by  N.D. 47.

He hears her voice under the Narration, answering an unse Interrogator (sounds like Phil). It's a job interview. Mi subtly, unconsciously shakes his head, as if to deny what his eyes see. The narration begins to fibrillate, again:
Armed with his personal files, she  was easily able to ingratiate herself  with the socially maladroit Milo --

The audio drops out as Milo sees uploaded medical files a ER photos of himself marked STANFORD MEDICAL CENTER: he's waxen, bloated, gasping for breath. With a certain dread, Milo jams the card in deeper:
...she planted the sesame seed both  to test the extent of his proclivity  and to provide a bonding experience,  since she would quote "save his life."
Milo is devastated, disbelieving. Now he sees real-time E footage: an Allergy Victim, bloated, twitching, gasping,  dying...
-- should it be needed Milo's allergy  is the ideal --
The audio crackles out. But Milo doesn't have the heart t bring it back: he can fill in the rest.
Randy traverses a well-lit tunnel. Still whistling.
Numb now, Milo clicks randomly: crime footage, personal  records, animations -- it all flies by with Chuck Worman- like speed.

Note that the cult members are found  reclining after swallowing the [click]  Syringe marks best hidden at base of  scrotum [click] mimics high blood  alcohol [click] indistinguishable  from kidney failure.
Milo closes his eyes, leans back: overwhelmed. Suddenly h sits forward, whispers almost fervently as he types:
Please don't be one of them.
Camera moves slowly through stacks of pre-school supplies toward a windowed door at the back of the room. RANDY appears in the window, lit ominously from below. He applies his swipe card.
Milo watches footage of Lisa taken by surveillance cam- e she is outside #21, trying to peek in the door.
...needs to be watched, due to her  heightened level of suspicion --
In one window, footage of Lisa casing the hallway before  going into Milo's office; in another, footage of her eati lunch with Milo.
-- and to her possible contagion of  key employees.
Milo clicks. A MAN's pair of mug shots appear. In the oth window, a grade-school yearbook photo of Lisa.
In August '86 Lisa informed her mother  of the sexual molestation by her  stepfather, and of his threat to  kill her should she tell anyone.
Milo watches streaming local news footage of a man being  taken from a courtroom in shackles (jerky, grainy). He's  lost the audio, but doesn't need it, anymore.
Randy climbs up to the main floor... whistling.
Milo watches eerie crime-scene footage: a Girl with her t slashed. But then, hearing nearly-distant whistling, he clicks on  windows furiously: closing them.
Randy rounds a corner. He enters the

The screens show the children's contour images, again. Wh Milo? Randy takes a seat at the same console Milo was at, and b to type. Camera booms slowly down beneath table-level to  find: MILO hanging onto the underside of the table, knuckles wh as he clings to metal table braces. The toes of his sneak are jammed into the space between a black plastic data to and the table bottom. Randy shifts in his seat, his knee rising toward Milo's b Milo arches it, avoids a knee by mere millimeters. RANDY: brings up a shot of a Programmer at work, zooms in his screen to begin collecting his code. MILO: begins to lose his grip as sweat forms on his brow  and, worse, on his hands. They're giving way. RANDY: clicks. A printer across the room start making a h copy of the purloined code. MILO: stares in horror as the data tower his toes are jam on top of starts to shift -- threatening to disengage fro its ports. He tries to lift it back up with heels of his  shoes. RANDY: knits his brow as his screen flickers. He keeps ty but starts to lower his head: he's going to look under th table. MILO: winces as he presses the tower upward with his heel while trying to maintain his balance... RANDY: lowering his head, keeps his eyes on the screen, h keys. Just as he is about to clear the level of the table the screen re-illumines. He comes back up. MILO: having extended his legs to support the tower, feel his hands slipping... RANDY: closes up the window... MILO: flops to the carpet(!) just as -- RANDY pushes away from the table... From the floor MILO watches him walk over to the printer, collect his  hardcopy, and disappear from view. Milo listens: the door clicks shut, the whistling recedes

Milo traces Randy's steps. He sees the door with the Civi Defense sticker, intuits how Randy got here, i.e, how one moves, unobserved, between the Day Care and #20. He sags against the wall. Wondering what to do, now.
Milo sits in his idling car, staring at his own house, up the street. How can he go in there? He puts the car in gear, does a U-Turn.
The Deux Chevaux is parked on the street outside a govern building. Not many people are around, yet. A Janitor hose down the sidewalk.
Milo slides a business card across a reception desk. It's the one the rumpled Prosecutor, Lyle Barton, gave him tha day in Palo Alto.
He gave me this. 'Said I should come  see him if --
He's not in yet.
Can I wait in his office?
It's locked, dear.
He looks over his shoulder, then back again, frightened.
Please.
Wait in his outer office.
Milo sits on a wooden bench, foot tapping. Hearing Barton voice, he comes to his feet. Barton enters with a Co-Work holding a container of coffee, discussing the particulars a case.
Do I make the call, or do you?
Milo is relieved the second he sees Barton's kindly face.
Mr. Barton, do you remember me?
...It's -- Milo, isn't it?
Yes sir. I need to talk to you.
Give me two seconds with Lacy here? (unlocks his door) Go on in, I won't be a moment.
Milo enters as Barton finishes up with his colleague.
I'll make the call, but I think you  need to send a Fax first (etc.).

Milo paces. He surveys framed diplomas, commendations and photos on the wall. He takes comfort in their solidity:  pictures of Barton's teenage Kids, Barton and Wife at the Grand Canyon. There's a college football photo, a young B with his team. Milo studies it, smiles. Move in on the ph till we see the number on Barton's Notre Dame football je ND 47. Milo's smile fades. It takes a moment before he even hear Barton behind him.
Milo?
Yeah. Hi. Thank you for seeing me.
Have a seat.
As Milo takes the seat in front of the desk (mind spinnin Barton moves to his own chair.
What seems to be the problem? You  look a little upset.
I am. I am, sir.
What's he gonna say?
Milo?
My friend, my best friend, Teddy,  was killed in Silicon Valley.
My goodness.
It was racially motivated. He's  Chinese. He was. And... I know  sometimes the FBI gets involved with  that. Don't they?
If there's a Civil Rights violation.  But generally we let the local police  and DA do their work first.
I -- just wanna help bring these  guys to justice. They're neo-Nazis.
Let me look into it, see what's being  done. Frankly, it's not my area.
(he gets up) 'Just didn't know who else to talk  to.
(circles an arm over  Milo) And Outpost? You're happy there?
Yes sir.
Alice is on the phone in the front room. Agitated, she pu on a pencil (surrogate cigarette). We hear Phil through t receiver:
'Didn't mention he was going to the  Justice Department?
No.
Not like him, is it? To do a thing  like that without telling you. You're  not losing your hold on him, are  you?
He'll tell me when he gets home.
That'll be a test, won't it?
Instead of busting my chops you should  do something about that girl. Fire  her. Or something.
Lisa's an extremely valuable member  of the Skywire team. We've got our  eyes on her. You keep yours on Milo.
(as she hangs up) Prick.
Milo comes up the path. He pauses as he nears the door: h not sure he can pull this off.
As Milo enters, Alice rushes to meet him.
It's almost nine, I've been so  worried! (she takes his hands) What did you see in there?
Nothing.
Nothing?
She watches him as he collapses onto the couch.
It's what they said it is. An  unfinished broadcast studio. You  were right... I just drove to Seattle  and back.
...Why?
Remember Lyle Barton?
She shakes her head.
The Justice Department guy who came  to the apartment when --
I remember.
After I broke into 21 -- which was  insane, thank God they didn't catch  me! -- I just drove around. Trying  to figure out what possessed me. You  know what? I've been putting my own  guilt on Gary.
Guilt?
(quietly) If I'd stayed down there, maybe this  wouldn't've happened.
Poor baby. You know that's not true.

She sits by him, touches her hand to his face tenderly. H closes his eyes for a moment, steels himself to her touch Then he forces himself to cup his hand over hers. But he can't stand it. He gets up, looks out the window.
I thought, instead of indulging all  these paranoid delusions, risking my  job, alienating Gary, scaring you, I  should do something useful with my  grief. Help them find Teddy's killers.
He doesn't see her smile: is that all. Assuming an  appropriately concerned expression, she moves toward him:
I was so worried about you.

She turns him around, kisses him. Her eyes are closed. Hi remain open. He's looking at her. Trying to comprehend th treachery. She touches him, breathes heavily. She wants more than ki to prove to herself how wrong Phil was, her professional  pride insulted. Or perhaps it's more personal than that,  especially with Lisa as a potential rival.
(through their kisses) ...been such a long night.
But she doesn't stop. She moans as she presses herself to him: wants proof of his devotion.
He's on top of her in the moment just after. Her eyes are closed. He stares at her -- glares at her -- with what we recognize as spent anger.
That was -- different.
...Different?
Shit. She knows.
You didn't feel it? So intense.
What's clear is, she liked it. A clap of thunder takes us to:
It's pouring. Milo stands outside, wearing a slicker, loo in the window at someone.
Lisa reads a paperback at a table, a slice of pizza on he plate, an umbrella hooked to her chair. Sensing someone  standing over her, she looks up. She smiles.
So you're not avoiding me.
Milo sits across from her. He doesn't know where to start
What's wrong?
He looks around, wants to make sure no one's listening. H speaks very quietly.
I snuck into #21.
Why would you do a thing like --
You thought about it too. You've  been suspicious for a while. But  it's not happening in there. It's  happening in the Day Care.
The Day Care?
Two Men with even features enter the restaurant. One has laptop case slung over his shoulder.
Can we go someplace else?
They're in a bandshell. The rain falls heavily, drips off the eaves. She holds the filament from Teddy's workspace.

It's easy to know who the smart geeks  are, the schools tell 'em. They upload  medical files, school records,  pharmacy files. They'd be happy just  to steal code forever. But when a  program gets close to fruition. Like  Teddy. He was almost there.
But why would they --?

You know. There is no second place.  And what's the risk? The killings're   undetectable, they're hand-tailored,  they make "sense." I mean, they're  in the information business. They  have scenarios for all of us, too.  In case we find out too much.
She's peering at him. He reads her mind.
I'm not one of them. Not trying to  "suss you out."
She wants to believe him.
They killed my best friend! I'm living  with somebody they pay to go to bed  with me. Can't you trust somebody  just once? I don't wanna be alone  here.
His plea is so ardent, his humanity so transparent. But s can't quite do it.
I'm sorry, Milo... I'm sorry.
She smiles sadly as she backs away.
(forcefully) I know why you're so secretive. Why  you won't let anybody near you. (quieter) I know what he did to you.
Oh yeah?
She tries to sound tough; there are tears in her eyes.
So that's in my -- file?
He wants to comfort her. He takes a step toward her. She  shakes her head: no.
Is that my -- scenario? (when he hesitates) Tell me.
They'd frame him.
(horrified) He's out of prison?
(he nods) They're already watching you. If  they had to, they'd give him this  drug that mimics an alcoholic  blackout. He'd wake up not even  remembering his "act of revenge."
She draws her hands to her face as the facade cracks. She weeps silently. He moves to her, carefully, slowly, seein her fear, her trauma. He touches her shoulders. She tense tries to back away.
No.
But he holds on.
Nobody's gonna hurt you.
Slowly, he wraps his arms around her. She remains tense for a moment, then yields, pressing her face into his shoulder. The rain drums on the bandshell.  After a moment:
...Milo?
Hmm?
I always felt if a -- boy I liked  ever found out -- he'd run. He'd  think I was unclean.
No, no. Never.
She clings to him tightly, now, the wall of her mistrust  breached after all the years of pain, secrecy, shame. A wide shot: they hold each other, alone in the storm.
All his suspicions were allayed?
Alice nods. She sits in front of leather-bound books.
You're sure.
She's at Gary's house. On the hot seat. Phil and Randy wa her. Gary does, too, but deep in shadow, behind a desk, a remove. Rain falls heavily on the Lake.

He said it made sense that Gary's  code was like Teddy's, that that  cliche about great minds was true.  Said it was all about his own guilt. (she shrugs) Plus, he has a tendency to get Gary  mixed-up with his dad once in a while.  It always passes.
He wasn't acting?
I don't think he knows how.
Phil looks convinced. Gary doesn't.

From across the highway (cars with morning commuters whiz by) we see Milo pumping gas at a self-serve; Lisa fills-u in the next lane. Ostensibly, they have run into each oth on the way to work. They are smiling, casual. Only when we cut close do we see that their expressions b no connection to their words.
What about the FBI?
They've got this guy in the DOJ,  maybe others. We tell the wrong  person, it's over.
Who can we trust?
There's always a logical answer --  you just have to define the question.
She defines it:
How do you let go of a secret without  telling the wrong person.
She pretends to need help lifting her car hood: "a helple female." He comes over to help her.
We don't tell anybody. (she's puzzled) We tell everybody. At once. So there's  no secret left to protect. When  everybody knows, they don't dare  touch us.
Bob Shrot is on the phone. Behind him, a nerdy security  programmer, LEN DIETZ, is at the console that controls th security cameras (the ones Milo futzed with).
(into the phone) No, Tony can't fill in for you, he's  not at your authorization level.
Scrolling, Len knits his brow: he's found something odd.
Bob? You better look at this.
Milo checks Lisa's oil for her.
Do we post it on the Net?
There're so many disinformation sites  about Gary already. Where he has  devil's horns or they crop him in  with Saddam Hussein.
Shrot stands over Len's shoulder.
Could it be a glitch? Something the  construction workers caused?
Unlikely. All 14 cameras are frozen.  Do we call Randy and Phil? Tell 'em  there may have been a break-in?

Not yet. 'Love to bust my ass cause  I'm not in frigging Mensa. (walks to the window) I swear to God, it's that kid Milo,  I told 'em so in the first place,  but they didn't even wanna hear about  it. (turns to Len) Let's run a printout on card entries.
Milo shows Lisa the oil stick. She nods.
The mainstream media. TV, or a  newsmagazine.
Right. But Gary's tied-in to a lot  of media conglomerates. Have to be  careful who we pick.
We could cross-reference a data base  on media ownership. But not on our  own computers. Not even at home.
Certainly not at my happy home.
He slams the hood.
Shrot and Len watch a laser printer, as it spits out line after line after line of swipe card entries...
A LASER PRINTER spits out code. We are:
Milo watches new Skywire code emerge from his printer. Gary is in the doorway behind him: watching Milo, scrutin izing him. Sensing someone, Milo turns and looks.
Gary, hi.
You look a little tired.
I'm okay. It's going well!
'Have a look?
Sure.
Gary takes the page. As he reads it over:
Why did you move around so much?  When you were a kid.

...My dad was a compulsive gambler.  Only he didn't think he was. That  applied to guys who didn't have a  "system." "Losers," who played games  of chance. He could "read" people,  so chance had nothing to do with it.  No matter how deep a hole he dug  himself, he'd give you the whole  speech. And you'd better not point  out the obvious. (he shrugs) His creditors would catch up to him.  Loan sharks or whatever. He'd wake  us in the middle of the night. Off  we'd go, again.
What would you tell the kids? At  your new school? You had to come up  with a good story, right?
Milo thinks: he's testing me.
No. I just went deeper into the  machine. Preferred being the geek to  having to explain. Lying would've  been worse.
...Worse?

Cause he was a liar. And I hated  him. (mimicking a voice) "Get your head out of that machine,  wise up to the real world." The more  he mocked me the deeper I went. Cause  if being savvy meant being like him -- (he shrugs) Guess that's why I'm kind of clueless,  even now. Didn't cultivate my  conniving side. 'Not sure I even  have one.
Don't be so hard on yourself. With a  brain like yours, you could connive  with the best of 'em I bet.
Gary smiles. There's no way to read it.
Establish the humble building, in a Park.
Lisa and Milo sit together in front of a monitor. A Kid d his homework on a computer at the next table. Milo shakes his head, as he scrolls.
He's buying up pretty much everything:  cable companies, baby bells, picture  libraries, museum rights, film  archives... Getting ready for Skywire.
(she's thinking) What about "60 Minutes."
Yeah, they dig stuff like this. (he types, then reads) "CBS News has partnered with Outpost  Information Systems in a cable news  network due to launch Fall of 2001."
But still, you can't say CBS wouldn't  love to break something like --
(he's shaking his  head) Say there's just one "mole" working  there, like Barton at the DOJ. How  do we know he's not the guy we've  contacted? Or she? Or the guy she  works for?
At the next table, she notices a Lady reading Time.
Time?

(types, reads) Time-Warner has a 40 per cent stake  in Gary's set-top device. That also  takes out CNN. (scrolling & scrolling) "GE joins Outpost in new venture,"  which means NBC is out. "Disney joins  Outpost," ABC is out. "Outpost and  Newscorp in new deal," Fox is out.  Any of these places could have a  mole. Or all of 'em. (still scrolling) It's like a a continuous loop.
