We  can go to some alternative press  place that 1,000 people read, get  them and us killed. But anything big  enough for this is a parent of or a  subsidiary to something Gary's got a  finger in!
Shhh.
Sorry.
Milo?
She's thought of something. He's watching the nerdy Kid,  smiling sadly, perhaps identifying with him.
How close are you?
What?
He's got 12 satellites up. He's got  dishes on top of 21. He's building  this -- (gestures at the screen) mega-network for Skywire. Let's use  it.
Move in on Milo as he thinks it over with a mixture of  excitement and skepticism.
Milo and Lisa walk in the park outside the library, think it through.
We can't just assume they're standing  by to receive Skywire 12 months from  launch. I'd have to write in an aglet.
A what?

It's how on-line services push logos  they wanna sell you. You don't ask  for 'em, they just appear. 'Have to  work on it somewhere besides my office  or my house. And then the quality of  the broadcast wouldn't exactly be  digital, that's 12 months away.
But they'd still get the idea, right?
You'd have to design a graphic  interface to make the data pop. Maybe  some audio, too. To tie it all in to  Gary. How long would that take you?
It's a standard GUI. Once I've got a  concept, it's maybe three day's work.
Gary knows I'm close on Skywire. We  have to do this fast.
Before they kill somebody else, too.
(a new wrinkle) Oh, man. I'd have to get into Gary's  house. To get the satellite positions.
You mean -- break in?
I don't know --
And what if the broadcast dishes on  top of 21 aren't hot yet? You said  the place isn't finished.
The complications pile up. They walk. They think.
I'll go look. (when he looks dubious) They'll just have a few more pictures  of me snooping around.
They come to a fountain and balustrade at the edge of the park, stop walking.
(looks at her) Why were you so careless?
I thought the worst they would do is  fire me. Who knew they took  termination so literally?
Gallows humor. What a game girl. He's nuts about her.
Why were you snooping in my office?
Oh. (she gets bashful) I liked you. I was checking you out.
He kisses her. There are no constraints now, there's no  "adulterous" guilt: they kiss with a passion deferred.
Slow push-in on the phone on Milo's desk: it's ringing.
Alice is calling him. Her face hardens, she hangs up.
As we pan the Best Western decor (in semi-darkness):
'Think everybody in this place is  here the same reason we are?
'Cause their apartments might be  bugged?
Milo grins. He & Lisa lie in bed.
I told Teddy about you.
What'd he say?
"A beautiful geek? What're the  chances?"
She smiles, rather bashfully.

I felt guilty. 'Cause I "owed so  much" to Alice. But even then I was  starting to wonder. Is it so great  to be so consumed by this one thing  that you let another person do your  thinking for you? If you have a  lucrative skill, it's all anybody  wants from you. You grow older but  you don't grow up. You turn into --  into --
Gary.
It's painful for him: losing a second father.

Larry used to say how the guys who  wrote the first cool operating  systems, like the UNIX guys at  Berkeley? They just gave it away.  They figured it was human knowledge,  it belonged to the world, like  Shakespeare or aspirin. 'Know what  I'm gonna do after we broadcast the  incriminating stuff? Air the Skywire  code. Then nobody can have a monopoly.
Alice is in bed. In the darkness, Milo comes in as quietl as possible. But she switches on the bedside lamp.
Where were you? (holding his gaze) You know you can't keep anything  from me.

Okay, yeah. I did something naughty...  There's this amazing Comix store in  Seattle. (is she buying it?) To tell you the truth, I did it once  or twice at Stanford. 'Guess I can't  keep anything from you...
Of course she buys it: it's in the file.
(she smiles) I won't turn you in.
Shrot and Len go over the print-out of the card entries.
Every entry was authorized.
Keep looking.
What're we looking for?
Any irregularity in the pattern.

Morning TV is on in the kitchen. A Seattle station airs a puff piece about a party at Gary's house: people in forma clothes (including Gary & his Wife) hold drinks and eat  canapes on the terrace over Lake Washington. (Gary's hair is different: it's file footage.)
Last years' party-goers pledged over  $2 million to the Museum; this year's  event promises to raise even more.  Lured in part by the chance to see  the stunning Boyd house...
Alice, grinding coffee, isn't paying attention. Milo is.
Look at this.
What?
Why doesn't he ask us to his party.  He's never even met you.
He has thousands of employees, Milo --
It's for the Museum. He knows you're  a painter. If anybody should be  invited --
Milo --

I know you think I'm too attached to  him, but still. I am close to Gary.  And you're the most meaningful person  in my life. (he gets up) I'm going back to the Comix place,  why should I be killing myself.
Milo, you --
